interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

div.p: 12 SepSeptember 1890 IocarIochdar, SSouth Uist Carnan
div.title: MaideanMaighdean Mhara
div.p: Duncan Maclellan, Carnan

Hair like the roinneach mhara
& skin like the trosg: all above waist
appeared. The first time she came
am barr remained about 15 minminutes
& next time about five minminutes. We
told this on our return to the Carnan
people who said this was not new
to them who often saw her in
the Linne Mhucanaich – skin like
that of a fish in spots. Going to Glas-
gow with eggs, fish & pigs. Other
four men with him

Duncan saw muc mhara who
acopaccompanied their boat from Loch Suainart
to Bay na Fala – her nose to stem of boat
all the way. Duncan threw a live
prat into the sea at her nose when
she sank quietly down throwing up
air bubblebubbles tossing the boat about
– from 70 to 80 feet long. She
was ballach.

fliodh – me Moire
Lus an acrais = unlucky to meet it be
cause a persperson is sure to be hungry ere
he gets out of it.

div.p:
This was a gentleman's datdaughter who fell
in love with a poor manman's son. She
went mad & ran away with the deer.
Her fathfather offoffered him a great reward
to catch her. He brotbrought her home when she
died. He died & was & they were buried
in same cladh. A tree grew from each
grave & found cut, grew, cut boards
for talisg joined Bodies left & put in one
grave.

Along with BaileBaillie John Maccallum
went to see old Ionnor Lochaidh Castle
after that walked to Banaovi. In the
evening BaileBaillie Maccallum drove me
with carriage and pair up Glenevis
to head of Glen One half or more right
round Ben-nevis. Magnificent scenery
The nevis runs level and land on
either bank level for many miles.
By a Glen coe man

div.title: Gleann Li-un
div.p:
Name
Cama ghleann dudubh nan clach.
32 miles long. Battle fotfought between
the Robertson Campbells & Mac
Gregor & the Clann Imhear.
Killed the Macivors outoutright. They then
went to Breadalbane. The Mac
grigors came down from Bun
rainich. They battle at Lagan
a chatha & stopped at Ceann
Chnoc at Camus nan carn.
The men washed themselves
& arms at Ford Li'un & the river
was ran red with blood. There
a man said. Bho lalatha nighe
nan arm bith Li'un mar
ainm air Diubh. {Sraid – Srath
Dubh-uisg. Where the
river ran before – silent water
remains there still –
where the river ran before.
My informant killed two otters
here with one shot.

div.title: Observations
div.p:
Corra chnamh. The sitt
ing posture of a milk
maid with her knees
half bent & the skirt
of her garment folded
on her heels to support
her instead of a stool.

Fuath,
Is considered an invissibleinvisible
spirit generally in a
whirelwhirl wind & in sec-
luded places or felt
at wakes of wicked
people. A bad omen
for any family as they
are to looselose all their
possessionpossessions shortly.

div.title: Cuthag
div.p:
In the event of the Cuckoo
being heard early in the
morning, between two houses
occupied by the same family,
and one or more of them,
sleeping in the an outhouse,
that there was separation
of coolness to exhist be-
tween them JJohn EEwen McRury

Lus an acrais,
It has been difinatelydefinately
prescribed as a danger
ous plant to sicken &
weaken people. It
grows from "Night
Soil" produced from
food taken without face grace
or offer sings, of thank-
fullness. If a person stepsteps
over, or very near it, it
has effect on them -

This word "MianMiann" is not gener
ally understood in its
original meaning by the
bulk of gaelic speaking
people. It is supposed
according to tradition
that a drop of "fual" or
"wine" direct from either
sex if put in any eatables
would create or kindle
a spark of flaming
love in the bosom of
the party taking it.

div.title: Butterfly
div.p:
The "DalanDealan De" of golden
colour is considered of
great importance at
the time of death,
If seen after, flying
over the remains, whether
in coffin or shroud it was
supposed the spirit was,
in heaven. There is only
one class of "DalanDealan De,"
of medium size & of fine
yellowish colour, like gold.
"All the other kinds are of
moss, or other worms,
such as the grub, turning
into flies. JJohn EEwen MRMcRury

Liu.
Is a gaelic word of
extensive meaning for
instance Liu an teine.
Liu an Cruisgean. Cho
Liu uair, &c I herehear is
a very ancient game at
cards called Loin,
Evidently it means to
sweep away, to cancel
to banish to displace
I herehear is a fine & ten-
der fish on the British
shores called Liu.
(over)
It is very tender and
soft In September it
is in its season, and
on account of its de
liciousness it is called
"Iasg BaintigheaBaintighearna" or
Lady Fish. JJohn EEwen MRMcRury

Splang
A portion, division
share for example
the spawn of fish
before it separates is
generally termed
splang, Splang
also mean the half
of the live of fish, or
animal.

In one part of Skye a
colt or a filly is called
Bionach whereas in an-
other part of it the word
is changed into Biorach,
In Uist & Barra it is
generally termed Loth,
whether mascmasculine or femefemininee.

In Harris they term a
foal, Isean an eich (or
the chicken of the horse),
till they are six monthmonths,
and after that till they
are put in harness are
termed Spriodach, Faol
Searach, in Uist when
a foal is six monthmonths
it is generally termed both
afterwards Blianach,
Da-bhlianach Tri-bhliadh
nach, above that termed
horse or mare, a horse
is at its best at seven
a mare at nine if not
ill used, As long as the
four leggs of the animal
are right and the inside
sound good feeding and
cleaning will build up
the frame, JJohn EEwen MRMcRury

div.title: LaLatha Feill Mhicheil
div.p:
(In general) was observed
all over the country.
Every wife in the family
way had to go round as
local burying ground or
some other burying place
agreed upon previously
Believing that the sanc-
timonious odour of the
graves was sufficient
to prevent premature
birth. In like manner
every mare expected
to be in foal went rou-
nd it also 'A dol deas
aldeiseil a chlaidh' Going right
round it or following the
sun. There was no bridle
in the mouth of the animal
"Aodhstar" was the head
gear Cock-fitingCock-fighting was
also to the fore. Every
defeated cock went to
the schoolmaster gratusgratis
The winners were taken
back by their respective
masters, with a share
of the spoil. After all
the performances were
over the balls were held
one in each township and
many a ball terminated very
suddenly, by a severe fight.

Coithean or Cuman –
Bleoghean made by a
practical cooper varied in
size. It was always acco-
rding to the number of cattle
to be milked in the fold –
There were twelve staves in
it, a black and white in
sucession and the twelve
thtwelfth was five or size inches
higher and thicker at the
top. It was the handle.
In olden times the Coithean
is considered a good char-
acter for a dairy maid
If the staves showed their
original colour well of
fresh she was considered
clean an tidy, and qualified
to make better and cheese, well,
There was another of a smaller
kind called n "Noigean" both
of the same shape and make,

div.title: "Creag Eanraig"
div.p:
This creag or creagan are
about 250 ydsyards N.North E.East of the
Female Industrial School
Benbecula Tradition
says "Earnag" was a princess
and a daughter of the Dan-
ish King who came to Scot
land for her encoachment
or "leaba siubhla" her step
mother followed her in dis
guise to do away with her
and her issue, if a son
who was to become King at
a future date, and with
a witchcraft-club, "Slacan
draoghachddraoigheachd" struck the prin
cess, her son, & midwife and
all then beacame stones to
this very day. JJohn EEwen McRury

div.p:
An Callach
glucannach stuc
annach stach
annach.

ghior-lagach ghearlagach
ghoirleagach –
Le n'aona meann
deug ghiorlagach
ghearlagach ghoir-
leagach,
Deich laraichean
ri-gu-du, rag-gu-
da – ridhle loth
Le’n deich searrai-
ch ri-gu-du, ra-
gu-da ridhle loth
Naoidh bò mhaol
odhar le naoidh
laoich mhaol odhar
na 'n cois –
Ochd chailleach
lan ducha le –
n' ochd strolaich
ean dubha.
Seachd muchdan
biata buidhe siadh
ruith na'n {teuir deannaibh
Coig muchan
biata. Ceithir
iallan donna,
Tri drùidean
dubha Da
almanac chalamna gheala
coilleach is cearc
chearr

When a cow reached
ten years, a quoy
calf was not counted in soum
ing till she was
four years old so
as to keep the
"leibhidh" in full. The "leibhidh"
was kept in full
in the Long Island
till about the year
1810, when Lord –
MacDonald and Mac
Coinnich Bodhar
of Lewis introduce
ed new rules of sou
ming on their estates
Simply for to get
more money out
of the tenants.
Clanranald had
no such souming on
their extensive till
18201830. But those
tacksmen who held
ground under the
Still-bow tenure
could do saas they
pleased with their
own subjects.
My grandfather
in 1830 had actually
to send five heiffersheifers
to Barra from
Carinish North Uist
as Lord MacDonald
would not grant
on any account graz
ing to any person
and not only that
but other tenants
who was short
of full souming were
strictly prohibited
from giving it for full
value to their neigh
bours. The generous
laird of Barra gave
pasture to MacRae
& Cameron also
other two tenants
in the township of
Carinish. Beinn-
Mhor a chinn-a-
deas, was open
to all, even people
from Mull used
to send cattle &
horses there and
take them away
without paying
a fraction for
them. The curtail
ing
of the Common
in the Long island
was the first attempt
to saddle the indu
strious natives.

Under these circumsta
nces the tenants who
were unsuccessful in
rearing stock were not
benefited, and those who
were more lucky were
handicapedhandicapped in increase
ing their fortune in
an honest way. To put
it in the plain word
of one of their sons
deceased twenty years
ago, Mhill iad ("na
h' uachdaran) a chuid
a b' fhearr dheth 'n tuath
's cha do mhathaich
iad a chuid bu miosamhiosa.
Uanallach, Lambswool

Marbhanlach, wool
taken by the knife or
braxey.

Earannach wool
clipped at the usual
fleecing time, or pitted.

Leac. na Gruagaich
on the croft of Angus
MacAulay Liniclate
Benbecula, "Rudha –
chuidh Oib". Cuidh
Oib or Cuidh an Ob
ain was an old cattle
fold for generations im
memorial. Raoghull
MacRuaraidh a
Cuail descendant of
Clanranald was
tacksman of Torlum
& unless some milk
was poured in a
little hollow on
the leachd when
theythe dairy maid
was done milking
every night the cattle
were sure to be in
the corn before day
break but when there was
no milking cows in
the fold the gruagach
never interfered.
Ronald his son
who built oldtigh
Mho Mor-{cchochd na
Monadh followed his
fatherfather's practice in pouring
a share of the milk to
the gruagach or slender
woman of the
green garbe, When
Peter Nicholson from
Skye got Torlum
under still-bow ten-
ure from ClanRanald
he would not hear
of such sheer nonsense
but sheer necessity
compelled him to them
to the old custom
in giving an evening
contribution to the
gruagach, and he
became a firm be-
liever of the story,
Even sixteen men
failed to keep in
the cattle on one
occasion, The dam
age done to the corn
was great. This took
place about the beginning
of this century.

div.p:
Lachlan Mac
Ruaraidh Ardmoine
Iochdar was one
day seeking a strayed
stirk in the Month
of February about sixty
years ago, after all
his dilligentdiligent search
ing about the borders
of Lochbee, he reso
lved to give it up as
it was beginning to
get dark and when
he was closing upon
Taigh Cloiche of
Mointeach an Iochdar
he observed as he thought
all the Iochdar men
dividing land for
lazy beds, and made
straight for them
It was after sunset
but the western hor
izon was quite clear
When within a few
score yeardsyards of thethem
his wonder was in
creased by the great
number of men as
he thought before him
He being in sh such
a hurry to join the com
pany did not look
very keenly at them
till he was in the
outskirtskirts of the
crowd, when they all
give a sort of an
unearthly screech
or scream that nearly
lifted him out of his
shoes. A sudden glance
revealed to him that
they were not the
Iochdar people
for they all wore a
green long garbegarb and
a sort of greendgreened soft
headdress shadowing
their foreheads
Their faces were long
and slim and entirely
different from natur
al beings They faced
him all in a sudden
"ach cha deach e
air mhiapadh, he
did not go back
but in a loud frighten
ed tone addressed
them in his mother tongutongue
Fhir a chuir mise chon
an t-saoghail, ma
chuireas sibh oramsa
cuiridh mi a h'uile
srad 's a' ghuim
ribh. When they heard
his determined ex
pression, they dis-
appeared into the
Taigh Cloiche, as if
pouring seeds
with a sieve into
a loban.

In olden times the
Inhabitants of the
Outer Hebrides when
Milk was spilt would
say "Coma libhleibh dheth,
tha bial feumach a
feathamhfeitheam air," mean-
ing that there was
a thirsty mouth –
waiting for it somewhere
else, and that the
party would get thetheir
quenched.

div.p:
Lonachain the rope
from the steps or
cassachan of the
loom, "Lona" a rope
old gailic.

div.title: Cochair
div.p:
"Cochair." an old Gaelic
word, signifying a small
gift given with a good
warm feeling

MacCallain Duncan
Mc.Innes Balavanich
Benbecula was known
far and wide for his
power of Frith making.

On one occasion a
boat with four men
were driven, by a severe
storm from the N.North EEast
off the coast of Uig
Lewis. The idea was
at the time that the
boat was swamped
and all perished but
as no wreckage was
cast on shore on
the west of Lewis
or Harris resembling
the belongings of the
boat people thought
they managed to get
on shore in the Flannan
Isles. A boat & crew
went there but got
no trace of the miss
ing boat.

People advised
the nearest relative
of the missing crew
to visit MacCallen
in Benbecula and
he lost no time in doing
so. In his arrival at
his destination Mac
Callen received him
hospitably and told
him to at rest
It was late at night
for to make a Frith
but early the following
morning he told him
that his missing friends
were all well on
the IslanIsland of St
Kilda, and were actually
killing & flaying a
cow along with
some of the natives
and that they could
not come home till
the Month of March
This happened in Winter.

On another occasion
a fine young man
from Howgarry
North Uist was
drowned and his
remains could not
be drowned found,

His father
weeks after the
accident visited
MacCallen and
he told him to
go back at onconce
and that his son
was lying face
downward under
a quantity of sea-
weed in a "geobha"
at the point of
Ard-a-Runaira
Balranald.

Instances of this
sort could be followed
to a great length.

div.title: TogalTogail an DoinisDonais
div.p:
This extraordinary stroke
of art in olden times
was very effectual am-
ong the inhabitants of
the North. When anything
was stollenstolen, and no
clear clue attached {could be found
to any person in par-
ticular, all under sus-
pissionsuspicion were named out
by the looser to the
party gifted with the
art, their names were
written on parchment
or paper, and if the
party could not write
there was a different
mark for every one
under suspissionsuspicion.
The paper was fould
edfolded longways, and rub
bed between the pamspalms
of his hand, and in
the name of the Dev
il allowed to fall
gently into a basin
or a big bowl full
of cold water. If the
name of the guilty
party was among them
it would go to the
bottom and the rest
would float on
on the surface. Then the party
possessed of the art
was to inform the thief
of what happened and
unless the stoltenstolen move
property was restored
to the rightful owner right
ful owner within three days
the whole affair was
proclaimed publicly
and would be compelled
to submit.

They greatly object
ed to the raising fo
the DDevil as sever yrsyears
famin famine was
sure to follow in
the township after
that.

Gheibhlaid
or
Geibhlaid

Is aan ancient gaelic
word for with a
very comprehensive
meaning. It is appli
cable to both man
and beast.

It means a wirey
thin diminutive –
object which does
not grow in bone
and flesh accord-
ing to his or her age.
Nach be gheiblaidgheabhlaid
e (or i)

When leading cattle
to or from the house
to avoid being bewitch
ed, one or more of
the number was left -
behind the heardherd (man
or woman) following the
rest at their leisure
"a deanamh an rathaid
dhaibh fhein." This was
sufficient to shield them
from the evil eye as the
number was not before
the person in charge.

If a man was to praise
the Stock in plain words
in the hearing of the bua
chailebuachailleor herd, the herd
was at once ready enough
to overpraise them, for
instance "Nach ann agad
a tha na h-aighean briadhabriagha
'S answer – Cha neil a
leitheadean anns an
duthaich.

div.title: Goisteachd
div.p:
I remember when a
school boy of Goist-
eachd being a common
saying with us,

If I were bristeadh
rudan with another
and blood issuing
from the knuckles
of either of us the
one producing blood
put it on the bare
skin of the other and
say roinn mi
goisteachd riut,
signifying that we
were friends in all
plays henceforth, but
very often the friend
ship did not last very
long, for as soon
as play commenced
every one so positive
we were sure to fall
out, and ultimately
end the dispuitdispute with
blood which very
often produced more
blood than on the
occasion on which
we made the goist
eachd. However there
was something in it
as the goistidhean
showed a warm
side to each other
"an am cruaidh chais
in time of hardship,
If I were to put the
blood on the bare
hand of a girl for
it was mostly on
the back of the
hand the blood was
put "air cul an
duirn then they
would say "roinn
thu goisteachd rithe"
and that signified
that she was to be
one of my GodmotherGodmothers
and if I were to fall
in love with her I
dared not say a word
to her for my life
as goisteachd was made
with her, It was a
common occurrence
for boys to put a
drop of their blood
on the hands of
girls that were not
nice looking signify-
ing that they would
not have anything to
do with them as their
lovers. Nice young
girls did the same
on coarse wild boys.
JJohn EEwen McRury, 9/1/951895

div.title: Nine, Naodh
div.p:
The fairies are said
to be nine nines of yrsyears
sucking the brestbreast.
Nine nines in boyhood, Nine
nines in young manhood
Nine nines in Middle
man hood Nine nines
in old manhood, and
Nine nines to the brestbreast
of death "ri uchd bais"
JJohn EEwen McRury, 14/1/951895

Naogh naoghanan a deoldeoghail
nan cioch naoi 9 a nam corrachadh
naogh naoigh na oganach
naogh naogh na fhear
agh naogh naogh na dhann
fear (dol leis a bhiuthadh) naogh
naogh na dhean fhearagh
naogh naogh ri ucuchd bais
is dhi duile dhomh nan a
naoghannan D bha = 567 years.

AoutAbout 3 y 37 years ago
there was a man living
with his mother-in-law
in the township of Torlum
Benbecula. One evening the
cattle came to the door
as usual.

About 37 years ago one
Alexander Campbell, better
known a sgriob a cha-
bbair was living with
his step-mother Mor
nighean Ailein or Mrs
Alexander Morrison.
One evening by the end
of spring the cattle
came to the door as
usual with one ex-
ception. The missing
cow was Alexander's
tocher, the cow that was
given to his wife
on the occasion of their
marriage. Her name was
"Creachag". Sandy at
once went in search
of her. Shouting at the
very pitch of his
voice, Creachag, Crea
chag, while he was pass
ing by a small knoll
called "Sithean Beag"
and shouting for Creachag
he heard as it were
a voice coming from
the sithean saying Tha
mi so tha mi so, I am
here, I am here. He stood
all of a sudden as er-
ect as a pole but shak
ing from crown to toe
like an aspen leaf with
terror. Suddenly he grasped
at the idea that the
fairies were scarce
of meat and that they
took Creachag inside
while passing by along
with the rest. He
bolted at once for
home, and through want
of breath on his arrival
he frightened everyone
present with the glare
that was in his eyes
and from want of breath
it took him all his time
a while afterwards to
tell the awful tale that
Creachag was in the
Sithean. This extraordinary
revelation & consternation
caused a pannicpanic among
the all the members of the
family. The 'Sgriob's mother
-in-law got a hank of
coarse homespun flax
and put it three times
sunrise round him and
put him through it
three times and after
a short rime was
repeated she singed
his busky beard with
a straw for fear of
being taken into the
Sìthean. It was the
Echo of the rocks
that responded to
Alasters hoarse voice.
Angus Mc.Eachen
Grocer Torlum was
an eyewitness of the
above. Angus is still
living hail and hearty
& so is the Sgriob,
A beannachd –

div.p:
Deallanach beag liath
ri buanacha bac
Dealanach an uisge
Dealanach buidhe

div.title: Heigir or Eigir -
div.p:
was common term amo
ngst old highlanders and
often used as a nick-
name for half grown
boys, having a pale look
ing face long thin bones
and bent inwards Casan
cuiladh or cuile. It was
also applicable to ill fed
and ill clad men and
as beggers of small fea
tures and the term at
the present time I
believe has changed
to Eigear. For instance
nach be 'n t-eigear e
In all appearances Eigeir
was well knowknown to the
ancient Celt as I find
the same term applied
to half grown boys and
poorly looking men in
almost all the highlands
and islands. In Lewis
they pronounce the word
exactly as we do in Uist
when saying Leac O h'
eigir. In Skye they have
a softer tone and a longer
accent on it. Then on
the mainland especially in
Sutherland Shire the same
term is used but with
a short accent Loch-
broom and Gairloch
they pronounce it like
the Lewis people. All
along Lochcarron, Kin
tail, Glenelg, Arisaig
Ardnamurchan Mull
Islay &c. In Arran
they term a middle boy
of delicate appearance
Mulcach, but the term
Eigear is com
mon enough among
them especially the
old people who
says Uirnigh an Eig
earr, & cha dugain
heighear ort.

Al, & Fual.
Al is generally one
of the old Celtic
names for water.

For example the word as in
the proverb Al laradh
gu leidheas ghagan",

A mare's urine to heal haggs hacks}, Al geal
an old decease com-
mon to young people of
weak spine which
generally follows after
too much running in
hot weather.

Cloimh iondindair gu leitheas
dhriuchdan.

div.title: Prince Charlie
div.p:
When the beautiful
looking Prince was
in Benbecula after
the fatal battle
of Culloden he
slept in a small
Cot in Roshinis isle
of the North east
of the island, and
the people heard that
he and his followers
had no bed clothing
and each and all
of the them felt
sorry for his posi-
tion. A middle aged
woman. (unmarried)
whose name was Mac
Millan was so much
put about that she
set out on foot
at night and called
on the neighbouring
women and asked
them in the name
of mercy to set to
work with her to
make bed clothing
for their loving King
and rightful King.
An ainm na trocair
agus na Trianaid
nach cuidich sibh
leam gu aodach lai
dhe dheanamh a
Phrionnsa mo ghraidh
agus a Righ dligh-
each ar'n athrai
chean, Every one
heartly responded
to this with great
secrecy, the best
and finest wool
was selected for
the purpose in the
sun shine, but the
carding teasing and
spinning was done
at night after the
young and fast speak
ing toungstongues were in
the clutches of natu
ral sleep. With all
good will and willing
hand the warp was
made but the weaver
was sworn on painspain
of death that he
would not throw
a shuttle on it
during daylight
and that he was
to be unwell suffer
ing from slowfive
so as to keep all
away from the house
except those who
were implicated
in the sacred con
cearnconern. This being
done, it was walked
and washed in pure
running stream for
good luck to the
Prince, and dried
on the face of the
rocks of Ru-lach
dair na h-airde
an a vein of quar
tz which can be
seen to advantage
from the seashore
west of Nunton
house. This layer was
spoken of as "Stala
nan ban buaireas
ach" for their excite
ment during the
secret process.
Unfortunately for
all concerned in
the manufacture
the Prince left the
very night on which
the women went to meet
Nial MacEachain
and one or more
followers to gr
Thill iad dhach-
aidh fo lionn dubh
and after having a
private consultation
about the blankets
and what was to
be done with them
they all agreed out
of respect for the
Prince that no
living person would
ever sleep in them
and Nic Illa
Mhaoil became
possessor of the
fabric, which she
kept carefully
in her chest in a
warm place, and
many a tear was
sprinkled over them
especially on a cold
night, air eagal
gu faodadh an
t' oighre dligheach
a bhi ri cruaidh chas
air muir na tir.

When she was an
old woman she did
not make any prepar
ations ifto to make lion
an aodach for her-
self as was the cus-
tom of the country
in those days, On
her deathbed she
requested her friends
to dress her in the
Prince's blanket and
also told them to bury
her in virgin soil
where no sluasaid
would ever disturb
the dust of her much
appreciated blanket and
the ashes of her
body. She was buried
in the N.North E.East corner of
St Marys in Nunton
and there is a round
blue boulder of the
seashore oppositopposite her
heels, Some strangers
have found a resting
place in the same JJohn EEwen MrMcRury
corner, but I am
not aware of her
grave being encroach
ed upon. The found
ation of the house
in which she was
born and died in
was shown to me
by my uncle over
twenty years ago& It
is between Cuidhe-
chlachain Mhor
& f & rathad na h'airde
faide facing the NNorth
EEast. A great deal more could
be had regarding this, and strange
to say that I took any interest
in it.

Barrfeal is the
old wool of sheep still
on the top of new wool
For example if a sheep
was fleeced early in
the summer and the
wool unrisen, it was
necessary to cut the old
In an inch from the
skin and when the
New Wool grew the
old wool that was
left was on the top
and was knowknown as
Barrafeal The wool
growing below the
tail (not on the tail
itself) but about
the excrement chann-
ilchannel and between the
legs was knowknown as
Fiondarlach, The
same is applicable
to very thin beard
on young men,

div.title: Serpent
div.p:
1 Ged is min do chraic
ionn s mor do ghath
ad bheul, bha th
mar a' nathair, ga
do rathadh feinfhein.

2 Tha bana bhuisteach
Lubach mar a'nathair

3 Se 't iorabal is neo ch-
ronailla dhiot cleas na
nathrach.

4 Cho choch-shuileach
ris a'nathair lubaich
's cho min cul ri h'
earbul.

5 Bean na maise tha
neo fhialaidh 's lan
da na briathran blatha
Tha i mar an nathair
riabhach 's gath
na spiocaireachd
na nadar,

Clach Nathrach
Is an accumulation
of liquid matter from
the mouth of the
serpent and is alw-
ays found among
rank heather where
it is spiralled by
the serpent going con
stantly round the
stem or stalk till
all the matter ronan
is accumulated on it.
It gets very hard and
of a darkish colour
and light in proportion
to its size. I remember
when in School in Uig
Lewis of seeing one
about the size of a
small hen egg. It was
found by the herd-
boy of Croulista who
was sometimes attend
ing school with me
on the South side
of Suanaval hill.
It was greatly val
ued by the more in
tellegent people who
saw it, as it is
good for taking
away any bad or
rotten matter on
a wounded swelling or
cut. Serpents are
common enough
in Uig, but not of
a big Size. I remem
ber of one being killed
in the Glen on the public
road in the glen betw-
een Balnakill and
Miavaig Uig. It would
be about a foot
long but very thick
in proportions to its
length. Since then I
have seen plenty of
serpents but the
biggest was in the
Island of Mull in 1889.
It was dead on the public road
between Dairivaig
and Tobermory.

A Sealladh mu dh-
eireadh a Roca-Ba
rraidh. Air eir choslas
fhuaradh sealladh air
Roca Barraidh iomadh
bliadhna an deigh
dha dol fodha. Bha
faisneachd air a
deanamh le Seann
duine bh'air fas bo-
dhar le aois, OidheOidhche
dhuth dhorch an
deigh dha gabhail
mu thamh thachair
gun do thuit clo cad-
ail air. Thoisich e
ri mionalan mar gu
'm be paisde bhiodh
ann, air chor 's gun
do chuir a ghearain
bhocbochd a bh aige ion-
adh air muinntir eile
an taighe. Seall suas
a nighean or's a
t'seanabhean ciod
de tha cearr air
t-athair. Dh'eirich
an nighean suas is
dh'fhoineachd i dhe
th, ciod a bha cur
dragh air. Ach cha
d' thug e feart orra
Dh'fhoighneachd i
dheth an dara uair
ach cha do fhreag-
air e. Chuir i sin a
lamh air an aodach
agus chrath i e, ach
ged do chrath cha
do chairich. LigLeig
i'n eubha ris an fh-
eadhainn a bh'aig
an teine gu robh h'
athair a basach-
adh. Thug iad uile gu
leir leum asda cear-
ta-cruine-comhladh
bronnaich air thear
raich a cheann shuas
an taighe, lasadh
solus agus ge do las
cha robh a stigh
na chuireadh air a
chois e. Bha ghearain
cho fior chraiteach
a seirm na'n cluasan
's bha 'n doigh air
a robh e na shin
eadh nadara gu
leoir. Coma-co-
dhiu, rug fear aca
air ordag a choise
is dhradh e i is dh
uisg am bodach
is cuirnean falais
air gach gaoisne
bh' air a cheann ead-
ar ghruaig 'us fhia
saig. Dh'fhoineachd
a h uile haon riamh
a bial a cheile
ciod de bh' air.

Fhreagair e gu robh
rud nach robh air
gu'n riamh dhe dhaoine.
Gu robh e ann an
cruaidh ghleac ri
ceathairne ladair
a mhuintirmhuinntir Rhoca
Barraidh a bha
air eir choslais a
tighinn a thoir dile
air Barraidh a chuir
eadh fodha e cho
iosal ris an aigeal
shliognach. Is mar
e be gu robh easan
san leabaidh sa
cheart am, gum
biodh naigheachd
eile aig Barraidh
's aig a luchd-
aitichidh mu'n
failticheadh grian
an cor do'n ghailte
achd maireach.

Nuair a chuala
na daoine a chainnt
so sann a thoisich
iad o fhear liath
gu leanabh ri
fal mhagadh air
Nuair a bha iad
sgith a fanaid air
an duine bhochbhochd thuirt
e riutha Gu sorach
gur he gaire mu ao-
bhair a ghuil a
bh'aca ach mu'n
thigeadh ceann bl-
iadhna gu faiceadh
a huile haon aca
gu robh easag
fiar. Thuirt iad
rium gu n tragh-
adh moran dheth
gach seorsa eisg
air a chladach am
bliadhna agus na
dheidh sin nach bi-
odh e cho pailt.
Thuirt an ceannard
a bh' orra rium gu
'n deach Roca-Barr
aidh fodha seachd
gealaichean asg agus
seachd bliadhna
agus seachd ginealai
chean ro n' oidhche
ud agus gu robh
bliadhnachan gach
ginealaich mar
aireamh gach geal
aich mar aireamh
gach anns na sea
chd bliadhna.
Thuirt e mar an
ceudna Nu nuair
a bha Roca Barr
aidh fo h' aileachd
's fo lan dhithean
gu robh seachd seall
aidh air fir-iuil
innte air fad 's air
leud aire cho math
s gum biodh a fhr
adharc. Tha ars esan
an clach bheag
na laidhe air uach
dar sgala dhilion
fon 'urlar direach fo
d 'd chluais agus na
faighinn na'm dhorn i
nuair a thig Roca
Barraidh an uachd-
ar cha rachadh e fodha tuilleadh.
Thuirt e rium mar an
ceudna gu robh
Righ ur gu olc a
tighinn a ghabhail
seilbh air Barraidh
Gun tigeadh e mar nial gun
chuid mhaoin gun
chuid gun daoine agus
gu saraicheadh e
fein 's a ghionalach
gach sinn fhinn 's
ar gionalaich ach
gu falbhadh e mar
a thainig e mar nial
gun mhaoin gun chuid
gun daoine A chur
an sgiul an ath
ghearr thainig an tiasg
na thoranthorran marbh
agus beo anns gach
badhbagh us geodha
mu thiomachailthimchoill Bharr
aidh. Thoisich a h'
uile duine air a thoirt
dhachaidh 's ga ghre
idheadh sa deanamh
feum dheth cho, mar
a b' fhearr a dh' fhao
dadh iad. Coma-co
-leam na leat, cha robh
RocaBarraidh a tighinn
ris am barr na'n uachdar oidhche de na h-
oidhcheanan an deigh
dha dol a chadal
chunnaic e sealladh
a bha mor agus a chuir
fior iongnadh aair, Or leis
fhein gu'n d thainig a
cheatharna cheudna
ach a chunnaic e roimhe
ach ann an atharrach-
adh trusgain, agus thois
ich iad gu luthorluthmhor
lamhara ri cladh
ach an urlair aige
cala dhireach fo chlu
ais, airson greim fhao
tainn air a chloich
bhig anns an robh
bhuaidh. Thuirt fear dhiu
bh ris na faigheadh
iad a chlach agus a
tilgeadh air talamh
tioram an Roca Barraidh
nuair a dheireadh e
on ghrionail ghorm am
maireach, nach rach-
adh e fodha gu brath
na breithnich gu deir-
eadh an tsaoghail
Bha RocaBarraidh
gu bhi car uine ghearr
am maireach as cionn
uisgeachan a chuain
an iar. Dhuisg am
bodach bochd agus
dh' iarr e mar achan
aich air a chuid –
Mac agus clann a
naibidhean saod a
dheanamh air eisean
a thoirt am mairea-
ch comhla riubha
on a bha n' aiseag aca
(am bata aige fein)
cho fada o thir ri
falach cuain air a
Bheinn Bhearnaich, agus
ma bha an taisbeanadh
a chunnaic e agus na
briathran a labhair
iad fior, gu faigheadh
iad uile gu leir seal
ladh math air an
tir nach fhaca iad
riamh. Sann mar so
a bha dh' aontaich
an oigridh le aois,
agus chuir aois a
sheula ri guim na
hoige. Cho moch 's
gun danaig an latha
bu mhoiche na sin
a bha gach ni 's
neach na aite feinfhein
o fhear liath gu
leanabh 's chuir iad
an cul ri 'n dachaidh
san aghaidh air –
cuan gorm na h'aird
an iar. Bha iad a
seoladh gu siubh
lach sleamhainn re
idh, a call sealla
idh air fearann 's a
glacadh seallaidh air
chuan gus mu dheireadh
gun 'd thuirt an sean-
duine nach rachadh iad
na b' fhaide sguir a seol
adh 's thoisich fannadh
air a loman aithis
na' n deoladhdeoghladh an sruth
air falbh iad, ach
mo chreach cha b' fhada
gus an robh caochladh
sgiuil aca ri innse na
ruigeadh iad tir beo.
Thoisich an cuan mor
air goil sa dol troimhe
cheile 'na ghlinn 's na
bheannaibh 's na bhiasdalla
chd 's na sruthan fiar-
ach agus tarsuinn
air chor 's nach mor 's
nach robh iad fhein
san fhasaig air an
slugadh suas beo,
Ach ma bha bruail.
ean nan tonn uaine
a cur geilt agus ua-
mhas air an cridhe
Sann a bha aobhar
an uamhais ri fhai
cinn eadar iad 's
bunacha-bac san
aird an iar. Bha
an cuan fad o shealladh
agus cor na bheannaibh
'sna ghleannabh a sar
bhristeadh na chobhar
geal a o chirean na
beann gu camas nan
gleann. Thug iad
an ceart fhaire nach
togadh iad an siuil
far am bu mhodha a
bha bhocaich.

Ach mu dheireadh
thall chaidh an cur
troimhe cheile na
bu taodha laodha
fada bhuatha 's
thanaig e na bu trio
ma orra fhein, Leis
cho fior uamhasach
sa bha chuis, chaill
iad an tuigse sa seall
adh san claisleachd
comhla, ach am bodach
na aonar. Dho Dh-
iarr ora misneachd
a bhith aca nach robh
ann ach gaolaraich a
chuain a teicheadh
romh na bha gu t-
ighinn an uachdar
's gum biodh a leithid
eile ann an am dha
sioladh. An tiotadh
beag na dheigh sin
chunnaic iad talamh
tioram a nochdadh
a dhroma ri solus
an t'saoghail agus
ma chunnaic sann
a sin a bha fath
na smaointinn.

Bha iad a smaontain
gu robh iad leath-
ach eadar da Bharr
aidh ach chcha b' fhearr
Barraidh chreagach
aca fhein an coim
eas ris na bha fa
chomhair an suil
na deargainn-traghad
an taca ri muic-
mhara, De thagam air
dhaoibh air, ach
gu robh na beann-
tanan a b' airde 's
ghuirme, na ghlinn
bu bhriagha sa b' fh-
asgaiche na srath-
an bu chonardacomhnardra
agus na h' uillt bu
shiubhlaiche san
cladach bu shamh
aiche a chunnaic suil
na air an cuala
cluas riamh iom-
aradh ri fhaicinn
san Eilean alain
cearta-cruinne-comh
ladh. Nuair a bha
iad seachd sgith
a coimhead air, sa gabh
ail ionaidhiongnaidh dheth
chuir iad an aghaidh
ri n' iuil 's an cul ri
n' ainiuil, sann an
dol fodha na greine
chaill iad sealladh
air le duathar an
fheasgair 's iad dluth
air a chala dh' fhag
iad. Co dhiu na co
dheth thill iad dha-
chaidh gun mhain gu'n
dearadhdeargadh, s thug a h'
uile fear aca seachd
latha na seachdainn
ge b' fhada iad air
innsadhinnseadh na chunn-
aic na dh' fhairich
sna chuala e fhein
da nabaidhean fhein
's do gach neach a
dh' albhas fhalbh-
adh na thigeadh na
rathad. Chum e con-
altradh ri sean us
og, ri iomadh linn
is gionalach gus an
lalatha diugh Mar a
thuirt am bodach
b' fhior thainig a ch-
eud Mhac Neil gle
dhluth as a dheigh
sin, 's e fo chis aig
righ is ruddire 's
dhalbh a fear mu
dheireadh dhiubh
as gu chuid gu dligh-
eachd, fo chis aig maor
ruidire us rìgh 's cha
till e féin na aon
duine riamh aigaige a she
albhachadh coraich
ean eilean Bharraidh
gu brachbrath.

div.title: Dealan De
div.p:
Tha e air aithris ann
an cuid a dh' aiteach
an nach robh dealan
De riamh air an t-
saoghal gus an do
dheirich Criosda.

Agus gur h-ann as
an uaidh Naoimh
a thanaig iad uile
mach, air chor as gun
do sgaol iad air
feadh an domhain
gu hiomalanh-iomlan. Tha e air
a radh mar an cea
dna Nach nach fhagas
dealan De riamh
ann am measg dhaoine
anigidh na far am bi
drochd cainnt ga la-
bhairt na eadhoin ni
sam bith graneil air
a chleachadh na air
a chur an giomh

Tha iomadh seorsa
dealan De ann, ach
an seorsa air a bheil
sinn a deanamh co-
mraidhcomhraidh cha n' eil iad
cho fl fior phailt
ris gach seorsa eile
Tha an dealan De
ceart dluth air leithleth
orlach a d' fhad agus
tha e na's tagaiche
mu'n chom na h'aon
eile fo n' ainm 's cha
e sin a mhain ach tha
na sgiathan aig e ni
's coramacothrama ann a bhar
na gin de chach. Mar
an ceudna tha iad
air an comhdach le
itean ro bheag agus
ro ghrinn air an earbal
's cha neil sin air gin
do chach. Than deaferdiofar
mor anns na casan mar
an ceudna. Tha iad na
eolaiche ri casan du-
ine na casan a h' aon
do chach. Agus a bhar-
rachd air a sin tha
am mullach a chinn cho
coltach ri crun righ –
le frillilleacheach
le frillisneach mu'n
cuairt da a cha robh
bhriadha. Than an dath
a their tur eadar-dheal
aichte on dath a their
gach seorsa eile. Than
anns an dath, leath=
ach mu – leathach
eadar d or fior gh-
land agus sneachda
Tha e an comhnuidh
ri fhaicinn a snamh
gu seimh neo bhruaill-
eanadh os cionn corp
naoidheachan agus da-
oine math eile Mar
sin tha e na dheadh
chomhra le cuid, fhaic-
inn tiomachailtimchoill air corp.
Tha e air aithris mar
an ceudna agsu stri
och na sgiathan agus
na chom 's na cheann
air a cheart doigh 's
bha corp naomha an
t' slanairear air a phas
gadh san lionaodach
Tha seirm ro-mhais-
each aige seach am
'sam bith eile fo n' ain-
m Chauaile mi seolad-
ear a gradh gu faca
e aon fhear dhiubh
ann an taigh ann an
NorawayNorway agus chuaile
mi fear eile a gradh
gu faca e Dealan De
ann a ValuparscoValparaiso an
Ceann a deas America
Mar sin tha e cosbhail
gu bheil e comasach
air fuachd agus teas
fhulang. Biodh an sg-
eula mar a dh' fha-
odas e ach 's fheu-
dar dhuinn aideach
adh gu robh na
seana ghaidheal
gle bheachdail air
iomadh ni air ma
bheil sinne anns an
latha-diugh buail
teach air gabhail
seachad orra nuair
a thug iad fa near
cho mionadach
an t' eadar dheallach
adh a bha eadar an
da sheorsa chulagan
so.

div.title: Sean fhocail
div.p:
1 Miann ba braon
Miann caorach teas
Miann gaibhre gaoth
'S a bhi n ardan chreag.

2. A ghobhar bhinneach
Cheigeach stiorach –
Is cruaidh ceann
'S a 's geire druinnean

3. Ged is binn do mhigead
Ged 's romach fod sm-
Iogaill
Cha mhor thig a ghruith-
inn o 'd bhleanaich

4 Mar a sinne boch 0
's ann is cruaidhe
nadhaire.

5 Cleas na gaibhre
truaileadh diereadh
a bhaine,

6 Cullag ceann uilt
le bridh s le sult,
Cullag a bheadh=
naich 's beag a stiach
e i

div.title: Meteor,
div.p:
Meteors are not
uncommon all over
Scotland. The first I
saw was on a Sunday
evening about Sun
set in OctOctober 1872.

It was a rare sig
ht. It came down
at a very slow rate
in a spirally sort
of way and leaving
a train of faint
fire behind it. It
was about two miles dis
tant from where I
was it fell. Others
saw it also, and
predicted a death
within a few days
and strange to say
a woman died
very near the place
it fell a few daydays
afterwards. I heard
very often about dregs
long before that.
If the meteor is
seen early on the ni
ght it is a sign of
some persons death
withing a short per
iod but if tis late
at night the death
might not occur
for a year or so.

If they are pass-
ing in the air during
day light they are
not seen, but I
heard of a very
singular incident in
in which two women
were greatly alarmed.
Both were engaged
cutting heather for
drying purposes on the
side of Cnoc-na-
glas-ainichean-
when they heard
something with a
peculiar force st
rick the ground be
hind them. On turn-
ing round to see what
it was they were
much amazed to
see smoke issue from
a heathery knoll a
short distance from
them. They went to the
spot to see if put
it on fire but there
was no person to be
seen far or near to it
but themselves. The
knoll or gropoangnoban was
soon de re-duced to ash
es and upon a closer
examination they dis
covered something
pinkish in colour
and about the size
of a mans fist
deposited in the
virgin soil and the
heat from it, was
too much for them
to ll handle it. It was
very like smithy
sinders This took pla
ce about two o'
clock P.M in the month
of July and
no person have died
there yet.

div.title: Crodh MarraMara
div.p:
Long ago there was a
tradition very common in
North Uist to this effect.
The sea cattle were
always seen sporting
themselves quite close
to the land, and occ-
asionally coming on
shore. It so happened
that there was a
man in HowarryHowgarry who
was loosinglosing his chil-
dren in infancy and
likewise loosinglosing his
cattle till he was re-duced
to nothing.

OnOne winter the sea-
cattle were seen sport
ing themselves pretty
close to land and
shortly afterwards
there was a fine
fold of cattle all
spotted in the most
peculiar manner, red
and white. Some of them
showed the signs of
giving milk. At a cer-
tain stage of the tide
they would take to the
sea and always land
ed about the same
time. However this poor
man thought to do the
best of the worst &
consulted a man of old
age who was much re-
spected for his wisdom
This wise man told
him to get some
black loam 'ùir –
dhubh' from a burying-
place and if he
could get between
them and the shore
and manage to throw
ùir on any of them
that the same would
be prevented from
following the rest
to their shealings
in the blue deep
He did as he was
told and the following
day they appeared
again, and as soon
as they were all on
dry land he ran as
fast as he could
and at seeing him
they all lowed loudly
and fling their tails
in a spiral on their
rumps and made for
the deep. At all events
he managed to throw
a handful of black
soil on a choice young
looking cow, and
she suddenly stopped
but and gave one
melancholy low
as if bidding fare
well to the rest.
He took her home
and fed her with
fiminfeamainn chirinchirean and
before she was six
monthmonths in his poss-
ession she drapped
a beautiful gray
calf the same colour
as her-self red and
white. He called her
by name CirinCirean on
account of living on
that marine plant
mostly, and the calf
was called gruaig-
ean. She milked a flow
of milk with rich pro-
duce, but she went
once a year for a
day to he former
shealing to meet her
companion, an tarbh
breac dearg the spo-
tled red bull, but
always came home
chewing her cud.
To make a long story
short she was in
his possession for
fourteen years, and
he was in po full
stock of lovely
cattle. It so happen
ed on a cold winter spring
night that the old
man said to his wife
when in bed, we did
not sleep without
produce to our keep-
per since we got Cir
inCirean till tonight and
if she livelives to feed
the calf she is carry
ing. I will kill her
next winter. When he
rose next morning
there was a beaut fine
calf lying dead at
her hind hoofshooves. She
had plenty of rich
milk as usual, but
when the time came to
visit her favourite
shealing and compan
ion, an tarbh breac-
dearg she took to the
blue deep and re-
turned no more.
However she left
a breed of good
cattle in the long
island. The progeny
of Gruaigean, as
from that very
day to this day
the two Uists were
never without plenty
of cattle called
GruagainGruaigean.

div.title:
Cailleach Bheag
an fhasaich
div.p:
O chionn fada bha
duine bochd ann an
uachdar Bheinn na-
faolach ris an cana-
dh iad Iagan-lom oir
cha d' thanaig gaoisne
fiasaig riamh robh
chraicion. Mar a dh-
eirich do'n chuid mhor
do'n chionna-dhaoine
smaointich Iagan coir
gu robh e fhein cho math
coir air a n h'aon da
cho chreutairean a
gabhail comhnuidh
leis ri fear eile san
duthaich, augus agus mar
sin ruinnrinn e suas 'inntinn
gu posadh. Se leabh bhreac
fein a bha dhith air,
ach ca faigheadh e i
sann a stall a cheist?
Na faigheadh e te mhor
a bhiodh e na dheann-
ruith 's na leum a la-
's a dh'oichedh'oidhche a goban mharbhadh
i e ga dochann. Na
faigheadh e te bheag cha
bhiodh clith unnta le
cheile gu cumail taigh
na idir san teaghlach
na m be 's gum biodh
cronnachadh orra, agus
mar sin eadar gach ni
a bh' ann bha Iagan
bochd fo thrioblaid 'us
dragh inntinn fad –
iomadh latha agus
bliadhna. Air deireadh
nam porst, shuidhich
e inntinn air sgeime
a bha na cheann
fada roimhe sin. Be
sin gu falbhadh e gu
brath gus a faicheadh
e leth-bhreac fhein 's
nan diultadh i e gum
biodh a chairdean gu'n
fhios ac air, 's na gabh
adh i e bu mahth is
mar a gabhadh nach
biodh a dhith air ach
a shaothair s e rud a
bh'ann gun dh' fhalbh e
agus chuir e aghaidh
ris ceithir airdeanan
an athair agus chunn-
aig e feannag a scol-
adh an airde an athair
'si garracail agus s e
breannachadh a thug
Iagan a garracail
an eoin 'S granda thu!
Sgranda thu! Ruig na
Hearradh! Ruig na Hear
rradh! 's gheabh thu
bean ann! gheabh thu
bean ann! Lan chreid
Iagan gu robh fiosachd
aig an fhannaig ciod
a bha na bheachd
agus ghabh e roimhe.
A dh' olc na dh'ioean
gan do thachair ris
A fhuair e chas air
talamh tioram 's na
Hearradh, s bha sgith
fann, airsneallach
gu'n duine gun daoine
sa feasgar a ciarradh
gun fhios ca 'n cuireadh
e seachad an oidhche
Gu fortannach chunn
aic e cailleachag
bheag anns an toma-
taich a tearnadh ma-
olaidh beinne agus
ealalch connaidh
orra 's i deanamh
direach air. Nuair a tha-
chair iad ri cheile
dh' eoraich i dheth
co as a thainig e na
co bu daoine dha
agus thuirt Iagan
bochd riutha nach ro
chuideachd ach tearc
's gu rorobh dhuthaich
fad as a so. Ma ta
arsa chailleach se
do bheatha fuireach
comhla rium fhin 's ré
m phaisde nochd,

Dh' aontaich Iagan gu
so a dheanamh.
Se rud a bh' ann gun
do dh' fhalbh iad a
cheart co reidh ri
da cheann eich a bh-
iodh 's a n' aona cha-
raid fad sheachd bl-
iadhna cha b' fhada
bruthag bheag ann
an iuchd eadar da
chreig fo bhonn beinne
ri aodan a chuain
's bha de gach seorsa
shligean maoraich
mor thiomchail na
fardraich cho tiugh
sa bha na h' itean
air ianlaidh na' n
sheur. Nuair a cha-
idh iad a steach
's a dhinnis a mathair
do'n ighinn amar a tha-
chair an t' ogannach
rithe, dhaltaich an
te og Iagan gu fao-
laidh 's dh' iar e air
teannadh a nuas ris
a ghealbhan. Chuala
e an guth acc cha'n
fhacc e neach leis cho
dorcha sa bha turlach
Chuireadh connadh air
an teine agus an uair
a thigeadh lasag as
or leis gu robh e faic
inn creutair a gluasa
d taobh thall an teine
mar fhalas, ach thuig
eadh e an guth math
gu leor. Coma co dhiu-
ghabh an teine 's chunn
aic Iagan a mhaide
an 's bi sin a mhaise,
a mhac samhailte fein
cho cuinleach ri fhalas
Ge be biadh a bha dol
fhuair e roinn deth
le mor shuilbhaireachd
is roinn iad gach ni
nar'n comas gus gach
comhfhurtachd agus
cadal a bhi aige an
oicheoidhche sin. Cha robh
ann ach seid a ronai-
ch 's a luachair an ois
ean a bhothain, agus o
nach robh fios co bu
cual na b' oadhadh
don leaba chaidh a
chailleach sa mhia-
dhoin an nighean air
a bealaobh 'us Iagan
air a culaobh, sa leith
iad sin do thriuir cha'n
fhaca mac na 'n t'
athair riamh air aon
cheann aghard. Cho
math 's cho blaith 'us gan
robh an leaba cha d'
fhuair an dithis oga
na dhaotas mi a
leithid a chainnt
a chleachdadh nor-
adh cadal ach a
faicinn aisligean air
a cheile agus da ri
reamh bu sin na h'
aileaganaisleagan, oganach
mar mheudachd giom
aich 'us gruagach ma
mheudachd breallaich
'us cailleach bheag ghre
annach mar chrubaig.
Nach bi n' atair an
t' seid a chuideachd?
Nuair a thannaig an la-
tha bha an disdithis oga
cheart cho taobhach
ri cheile sa bha iad
cho chollach ri cheile
Se rud a bh' ann roinn
iad air air son posaidh
agus air an rathad cha
deach iad seachad
air lon na lodan gun
chromadh os a chionn
ga faicinn fhein ann
on cha robh na bh' fhearr
do sgathan aca. Nuair
a rainiag iad a fear
a bha gus an ceang
al le bhilibh dheora-
ich e co an sithean
a lig a mach iad
na co sgeir mhara
air an deachaidh an
arach. Roinneadh am
posadh co dhiu agus
thoisich a bhannais
nach fhacas fhat-
ast a leithid sna
Hearradh. Bha crios-
an beag caol cruaidh
naodh dual 's gach
dath a bha sa bhogha
fhrois ann mu leisridh
na caillich agus sna
im air cho tric sa
bha roc an cridhe
deanadh Dhuasgail
i a chued shnaim, 's
na dhuasgail sann
an sin a bha sealladh
cha robh seorsa eoin
air na chuir neach ri
amh fhiacail nach
robh cearta cruinne
comhladh a gitaell
aich mu'n taigh aice
is cha robh aice ach
a lamh a chuir orra
mar a dh-fheumadh i
sam maradh. Dh' fhua
asgail i a so an ath
shnaim ach ma dh' fh
uasgail sann an sin
a bha sealladh nach
bu laogha ionnadh
dad. Cha robh iasg
riamh a chliabhaich
ri traigh nach dan-
aig an cois na tuine
's cha robh aca ach
a fear a b' fhearr
leo lamh a chuir air
Dhuasgal i sin snaims
eile, 's ma dh' fhuasgail
sann an sin a bha hui-
rle harla cha rodh
maorach riamh air
creig an na comhnuidh
san aigeal shlig-
nach nach ro cearta-
cruinne, comhlabh,
fiach co b' fhaice a
gheabhadh air tir. Dh'
fhuasgail i so an cea
thramh snaim agus
chuir i sop feoir eadar
da dhuail sa chrios
's ma chuir, sann an
sin a bha sealladh 'sa
miallannaich. Cha ro-
seorsa ceithir-chasaich
a dh' ich biola feoir, na
thug bainne, no air an do
chuir duine rimah fiacail
nach robh ann am prioba
na suil mu 'n cuairt
dan bhruth 's cha robh aica
aca a rao raoghain diu-
bh Cha cha robh gainne
a fotainnfaotainn a cinn a
thogail na fardraich
fad sa mhair a bhan-
nais 's bi sin, a bhannais
da rireamh. Nuair a bha
iad seachd seann sgith
a githeadh sa g'ol de
gach seorsa b' fhearr na
cheile agus air a loman
athais a laidhe 's a g eir
idh smaointich Iagan
beag bochd gu deanadh
e fhein sa cheile saod
air an dachaidh fhein a
ruighin. Dh' fhalbh iad
air a la araidh agus on
nach b' urrain a chail-
leach mor bhochra thoirt
dhoibh thug i dual as
a chrios lachdfhionn
's chuir i mu mhiadhoin
Iagan e agus chuir i
cruaidh shnaoim air
Thuirt i ris air na chunn-
aic e riamh fa chomh-
air a dha shiulach gu
e ga fhuasgladh na id-
ir ga fhliuchadh air neo
gu 'n cailleadh a bhuaidh
Nam be 's gu gleidheadh
se e gu robh gach buaidh
nadara agus mhi nadara
ann agus gur a math a
bha fios a a paisdean
caomh fhein air buaidh
gach cluic agus gach
cleas Thug i mar an
ceudna, dual eile dan
chuis eagail a thanaig
as a churrach fann, sean,
seargta faein, is ann an
eiridh na graine dh' fhalbh
iad S ann a sin a bha
charaich Iagan beag gra-
nnach cairtidh lachdun
seargta, 's e mu airde bo-
trachain agus ise na top-
aig bhig bhidaich char-
taidh, chrainntidh le da
chuil bheag bhiorach dhubh
mar gu faiceadh tu gaois-
nean air tighinn beo ann
a lon. A dh' aon fhacal
bha i cho neo sgeadasach
ri gin a chunnaic duine
rimah, bu choltaiche i
ri clodha-linn, na ri
bana-chrisdaidh.
Ge de dha sin bha
dh' eifeachd na criosan
beag caol cruaidh na
chuireadh bain tighearna
na geilt. Co dhiu ran-
aig iad dhachaidh Ma
ranaig sann a bha an
t'ionadh air muinntir cean-
huas Bheinn na farlach
gun d' fhuair Iagan beag
bochd greannach bean
agus seachd araid a
mhac samhailte fhein
mar gum biodh iad air
a leigeadh ansn an aona
mholtair. Bha moran a
dol a chur failte air
Iagan is cha b' ann air
a shon fhein a mhain
ach air son sealladh
fhaiicnn de'n t'seorsa
mnathadh a t' fhuair e
's cha robh h' aon a dol
ann falamh na gruam-
ach. Bha sin gu math
taobh air thaobh, ach
da dha sin fasaidh
daoine sgith de gach
ni 's do gach neach.
Cha robh di no uir-
easbhuidh orra eadar
na bha iad a faotainn
o mhuinntir an eilean
's na bha tighinn uchda
leis an criosain lachd-
ionn a ceangaitle mu
meadhaoin a latha sa
dh' oidhche. Thuit e mach
nach robh na naibidh-
ean ch cuimhneach orra
sa b' abhaist dhoibh
agus se thainig as a chuis
gu do thoisich gach te
aig a robh beagan de
thoradh an t samhraidh
ri iondrainn an im sa
chais s cha robh fios
cia mar a bha e falbh
Thachair gu robh gill
og tapaidh guanach
lamh riutha agus se
rud a roinnn e dh'ol far
an robh Iagan s a bhean
's dh' innis e dhoibh gu
diamhair gu robh e fhein
ann a n' troma ghaol air
callaig aig bhainndidh
a bha cho briadha 's cho
flathail ris a ghrein ghil
's nach robh fios aige cia
mar a ghabhadh e greim
orra. Thuirt Eoraidh ris
oir bi so a cheud uair a ch
ualas a h'aimn na'n d' thug
adh e gaoisne de gruaig ga
hionnsuidh gu'n d' thugadh
ise orra gu siubhladh in a
seachd saoghail leis ge
be taobh a rahcadh e
agus sin air chumhnanta
gu 'n cumnadh e commadh
fad na duldachd Dh'
aontaich e so a dhean
amh. Dh' fhalbh mo laoch-
an 's e ga dheanamh fhein
lan cinnteachd gu rachadh
gach cuis leis gu math
's gu ro-mhath. Ranaig
e an fhardrach is ghabh
e steach air a mhagan
gu bog balbh samhach
a g' ialladh mar a b' fhearr
a dh' fhaodadh e a dhion-
nsuidh na cuil anns an
robh e a smaointuinn a ro-
b hi na cadal. Bha seana
na h' ighinn maill riu san
taigh a comhnuidh agus gu
mi fhortannach dhise agus
dhasan si bha na cadal
sa cheart oisean a ghabh
an gile ga ionnsidh. A dh'
olc na dh' eigin gan d' fh-
uair e fhuair e goisnean
guraige a thoirt as a ce-
ann gun i ga fhairiach-
adh agus liagair e mach
as an taigh cho faillidh
sa buirinn da Lomm e as
agus ranaig e Eoraidh ch-
oir sa nanail aig cho lu-
ath ri sgiath na lach-
an 's thug e dhith an gaoisne-
an. Ghrad chuir i e, air
airmadh gu math le le
smugaidean, sa chrios
agus cruaidh shnaim air.
Faodaidh tu dh'ol dhach-
aidh orsa ise 's cha n'eil
san duthaich o cheann na
sgarais uait i gu brath
Ranaig e dh'achaidh 's –
gagabh e gu tamh ach ma –
ghabh, cha b' ann gu cad
al, Cha luaithe dhuin a
shuil na dh' fharaich e
chramail sin ga sinneadh
fein sios ri thaobh, na
feileamainean aice cho
cruaidhe ri eisir 's cho fa-
aire ris an deith 's rug
i air amhaich air na
lamhan bochda cheart
cho teann sa b'urrainn
deth. Cha robh solus na
saoilse san tullaich 's cha
robh e tuigsin ider ca de
chuis eagail aig a robh
greim bais air ugainn air
na deich inninn. Nuair
a thig lalatha thig comhairle
'sa nuair a thainig a la
tha s a chunnaig e gus
chi seanamhair a bh' ai-
ge an aite ceamain thug
e am blar a mach air 's
ma thug lean a choill-
each e. Cha robh s an
duthaich na chumadh gu
t' seann te ach as a dhe-
idh. Ranaig e Eoraidh 's
dh' innis e dhi facal air
an fhacal mar a thachair
Thuirt i ris gu feumadh
e gaoisnean eile thoirt ieaise
i on' nach fhaodadh
e a thoirt as a ceann ach
gu'n fhiosdda cha robh aige
ach feathamh gu h'oicheh'oidhche
's a chailleach as a dheigh
mar gum biodh i as a rian
's ann an sin a bha i
Ranaig e ari a mhiogabh
's air a mhagabh cho fai-
lidh ri cat 's or leis gu
robh a cinntach gu leor
as a thuras fh'uair e gaol
na fuilt 's dh' fhalbh e
's ranaig Eoirridh 's thug e
dhith an gaoisnean fuilt
S huaind i e mu'n crios
lachdionn 's chuir i snaim
air 's dh' iarr i air a bhi
toirt a chasan leis dhach-
aidh. Ranaig e 's chaidh e
chadal 's ma chaidh cha
bu chadal ach dusgadh. Bha
mathair a leannan comhla
ri seanamhathair air a
mhuin 's ga thoirt o cheile,
gus fhios co b' fhearr coir air
Cha d' fhuair iad briobadh
cadal taobh air thaobh
Bha chuiss a bh' ann a cur
connuidh air ach cha do
leig e dad air. Thug e air
gu Eoiridh an treas uair
's dhinnis e dhith mar a
thachair. Tut ars' Eoir
idh sin mar a 's fhearr a
chuis bhiodh a mathair
agus a seanamhabhair agad
te gu gniomh 's te gu altru
m do shliochd ach thoir
dhachaidh dhomhas cli-
abh connaidh Roinn e
sin 's thuirt Eoraidh choir
ris a dh' fheachain a faig
head fuiltean a ghoid a
nochd 's na gu robh chuis
leis. Dhiallaidh e air fal-
bh 's a chridhe gu sgolt
adh na chom leis an
tollachadh, ranaig e
gu bog balbh samhach
sid e mhagan a dh' ion-
suidh na seide anns
an robh nighean is troinn
e e fhein lan chunntea-
chd as a thuras, ar leis
fhein an oidhche sin
Bha leannan na trom sh-
uain, an deich inninn
a chadail 's e sgith 's cho
failildh rim ac mathair
t' fhuair e gaoisnean a thoi
irt as a gruaig 's dh'
fhalbh e 's ranaig e n' a-
bhaist Eoiridh 's cha be
buaidheach i. Rug i air
a ghaoisnean 's chuir e
cheann san teine ga dh'-
athadh 'us chuaiulcheangail e e
mu crios 's chuir e crua-
idh shnaoim air 's thuirt
i ris nach robh anns
an t-saoghal na chuire-
adh eatarra gu brath
fhad sa ghleidheadh
ise crios. Dh' fhalbh e
dhachaidh, 's e seachd
seann sgith eadar a
huile alaban a bh' ann
's ghabh e gu tamh, ach
ma ghabh, sann a sin
a bha bhreisleach, 's an
cur troimhe cheile A sean
amhathair, 's a mathair
agus ni 's miosa seachd
uairean nan dithis, an
t-'seica a bha h' athair
a cairteadh gu caisbheart
dha fhein 's dh a theaghla-
ch uile, bog fuair, fluich
sallach a slachdaich
thall 's a bhos 's a cur
nam both dhith, ran-
bais aig an ogannach
's bu shuarrach easan 's-
each na boirionnaich
a ran dearg na ceann
is iad a deanamh
mar a dh' fhaodadh iad
fiach co bu dluithe bhiodh
air a ghile, an t' seice
gabhail dhoibh bog-fl-
uich mo shiad a gheibh-
each cobhair 's gun cho-
bhair ann dha, Lean iad
air an ioram so gu glas-
adh an latha gun dun-
nadh suil na lochadh
cadail DhiondrainDhionndrainn an
duine bochd eile a bhean
's a bhanachliomhain
an da oidhche ach cha
do shaoil e dad num
uine sin Dhinnis an triu
ir a beul a cheile faca
al an fhachal mar a thach
air. Chaidh an duthaich
gu gluasasd 's dh' fheum
ta Iagan is Eoraidh a
losgadh beo, thugadh
a choisir mar a bha iad
Iagan is Eoiridh na borra
nnaich 's an t seice 's an
togannach gu traigh
mhoir reidh thioran an
ceann a tuath an Eilean
Fhuar a mod ciontach
and dithis. Roinneadh
ceagal nan tri chaol
air Iagan Loisg iad
a ghruag aig Eoiridh
s thug iad uaithe na
criosan lachdionn 'S
chuir iad air ais do na
Hearradh i 's b' fhearr
nach d' thanaig i riamh
as Iar an do ruisgeadh
Eoiridh, sann a thiallaig
eadh na criosgan. Thoisich
iomaghaobhach mhor an
oidhche ein anns a chea
rt bhad a mhair latha
us bliadhna 's nach
faiceadh iad sion ach
siacban a dol mu' n cuairt
ann S e an Dun gaineach
ach a thug iad mar ainm
air an tor uamhasach a
chruinnich ann. Lean at t-
ris a bhaile do'n dunn
gus an la diugh ach
chnamh an dun le aois
's le gaoithe agus s e lion
suas a loch a bha fo
bhon a niar-thuath
Dungaineachadh a lalatha
diugh.

div.title: Sea weed
div.p:
Feamuinn Dearg is a
common term for all sorts
of seaweed washed on shore
from the low lying reef of the
Atlantic Then is a rarity
of other seaweeds amongst
il as Bruchd is applicable
to a great quantity washed
to shore at one time, tide,
or day.

1 Langadal a long thina
branchy seaweed growing
on a tangle of smooth
bark and the tangle it-
self is called Duibhean.

2 Roc is a long broad plant
nearly of the same colour
as langadale, but does
not show the same glossy
bark as the other. It resembles
very much Kent-lace and grows
to a great length and var
ies in breadth like the for
mer plant.

3 Liathag is a broad
plant resembling the shape
of flat fish very much, It
grows on shorter tangle
sometimes than the Langed-
al especially in shallow
water, but in deep water
and in a forest of sea-
weed several miles from
land the tangle itself is from
five to six feet. This is the
tangle that is so much pri
zed for its composition. It con-
tains 3 atoms of potash &
1 atom of carbonet of lime

4 When the Liathag spreads
into branches by the end
of spring and May these
branches are called

5 Bar-dearg. But after the
end of May when it is at
full length this is called
6 Bragair.

7 Smot is a great variety
of very fine seaweeds gener-
ally growing under the shelter
of the stronger plants, and
considered the most suitable
manure for any class of
soil as it contains all
sorts of ingrediants.

8 Caragean a well and
widely knowknown plant

9 Cirein a find small plant
resembling the cock's combe
of a dark-brown colour and
very sweet to the tatste and
considered wholesome.

10 Gruaigean a well known
plant with very glossy bark
and grows in small bunches
of a slender stalk with a
peculiar frill of thin edge
like lace on the stalks.
Some of the Gruaigean grows
as long as six inches but
it is not so tasty or sweet
then. Than e fas na bhagad-
ain mar gu'm biodh Bain-
tighearna le uichraichean air a crios.

11 Craigean a small plant
like the wide spread palm
of a baby and grows in sm-
all bunches here and there
and considered a splendid
poltus when properly mashed &
boiled for any sort of sore.

12. Feamuinn-Dubh a black
rank course plant grow
ing on the foreshores and
is not considred so ral
iable as other Sea weeds
on account of its small
percentage of potash
It contains 3 atoms' of
carbonate of lime & 1 of
potash.

13 Glearach a thin light
branchy plant dark brown
in colour.

14 Buidheagach a plant
of many branches with round
balls or bubbles It gener
ally grows on the foreshores

15 Builcean a sort of plant
resembling tanned string for
long lines and has an ob-
long bubble with very thick
skin and hardly any opening
inside.

16 Builcein-Mor a different
plant altogether though it
resembles the former to a
great extent. It has a
less number of bubbles or
balls, and the bubbles are
perfectly round and of a
far thinner skin sking and thothough
inside when opened the inside
is full of fine threads woven
in every direction like cob-
webs and when burnt its ashes
contain a good deal of mineral
matter.

17. Grapach a short thick
flat leaved plant with
unnumerable notches and small
holes round the border. It is very
unproductive as far as manure
is concerned.

18. Screagag a black plant
generally growing in sounds
and narrow channels much
covered with a little white spot
or pimple of the shape of a small
limpet shell, and contains a
great deal of Carbonate and
when heaped up and fermented
considered good manure.

It does not grow to any
great length as it is gen-
erally reaped by the action
of the sea unless artificially
cut at the end of three yrsyears
if the current is strong. Its
edges resemble the Combe
of the old common Cock
spreading into many brances.

19. Dulse a well known plant
to the majority of people.
It grows on tangles as well
as on rock or bodhachan

20 Slochdan a very
fine delicate plant and
good for human food
when cooked It generally
grows on flat rocks of
smooth surface of the
hardest nature. It is pretty
like Dulse only that it is
much thiner and finer and quite
transparent.

The following true
story will throw some light
on its use in the outer Heb
rides in this century. Duncan
Campbell, a native of Bread-
albane, and an Assembly
Schoolmaster was visiting
his neighbours and on being
invited to dinner he expressed
himself in the following
exraordinaryextraordinary manner.
Thugnaibh suas gu'ar
Dinnir comhla ruinn
a Mhr Campbell
Duncan replied –
Mu ta cha teid, tha
mi air mo dheadh
dinnir a ghabhail
an taigh AonaisAonghais-ic-
Phraisais, Bollaiche
todhair agus madaiche
feamunn anns le aran
math eorna.

21 Feamuinn Chirinn the
most productive of all
seaweed for Kelp it grows
higher than any other marine
plant. Just at the height
of tide and unlike other
sea weed is generally ex
posed to the elements of
nature for a period of 18
hours out of the twenty
four hours. It is one of the
best feeding stuff for cattle
when well boiled. The juice
should be allowed to cool
and two pints given to each
beast when stalled at night
and much as a person
could lift twice in his
hand of the feminn sixed
bith boan or clean chaff
or oats or bear or any
other sort of corn, three
times a week during the
month of March and April
It regulates cattle and cle
ans the inside and gives
a very glossy appearance
to the new hair in Summer.

div.title: Granet, Granite.
div.p:
Greoid is the gaelic
in Lews for Granite. There
is fine granite in Dalbeg
in Barvas, but in Uig there
is only the usual bastard
grantie. 15/2/951895 JJohn EEwen MRMcRury

Se sin a chuir am brea-
Clach-breac a thugh
thaigh a chonachair
'S a chuir an conachair
a thaigh a gheara-
bhric, An t-ioasad,

Cha robh fuaim mor
O shothach lan ramh
Ged 's beag do chron smor t ion
lag

Chaidh triuir gu carraig
thill an triuir, 's cha do
charrich a charraig,

lg.l: 'S mor a's misde e thu bhi ann
Ach nuair theid thusa cheardach Uilcean
Anns a ghleann 's nach bi ach nimh
A sheideadh a bhuilg aig a ghobhan

div.p:
Cho fad 's a tha cunntais ag-
ain 'S e Baile-nan-Cailleach
am Beinn-na Faolach an t-
aite mu dheireadh 's an robh
an comhlan beur, bearanta,
geur-chainnteach, sgatachsgaiteach
so mu dheireadh air chuairt Cha 'neChan e
bhain gu robh iad nan cuis
eagail anns gach duthaich
agus measg gach fiona
air son sgaitearachd an
cainnte ach mar an ceudna
bha iad na'n cuis ghrain
leis gach neach air son sga-
itearachd am fiacla air
gach seorsa b' fhearr na cheile
aig gach bord agus cuideachd
anns a suidheach iad. Dh'
itheadh iad a chuid a b'
fhearr 's chaineadh iad a
chuid bu mhiosa 's cha n'
fhaghadh iad rudan-ruadh
a dh' iosal na dh' uasal
gugun leobadh air gach taobh
bho'n'd thainig iad. Bha sia
deug dhiubh anns gach ban
ail, daoine mora colagara
ladairlaidir fiadhaich nan cruth
agus ro dhullaich ri'n smachd-
achadh nuair a chuirte n'dragh
na tuaircneadh bu luidhalugha
orra. Mar a bha chama-chomh-
ail an dan do Mhic-ic Ailein
t' fhuair a chearnatha uamh
sach so an cas air tir air dho-
idh eigin mar a thubhairt mi
am Beinn-na-Faolach no Beinn
a-bhaola mar a their cuid le
aithearachdaithghearrachd cainnte, 's o na bha
cuid is cothram mor math aig
Mac-ic Ailein thug e dhoibh
la aoidheachd an tosachtoiseach. Dh'
fheumadh iad feol ur mairt
a bhi aca h'uile latha a bh-
arrachd air a h'uile ni eile
b' urrainb' urrainn e chur fa comhair.

Bha na harrabhallaich a gith-
eadh 's go a g'ol a latha sa
dh'oidhche ach an tiotadh
beag a bhiodh iad na'n cadal
's cha robh an cadal fada air
uairibh. 'S tric a chuir rupal
an cuirp bhrein shallaich as
an leabaidh iad agus is math-
dh' fhaota neach ann glan
a dh' fhagadh iad i iomadh
madainn Ge math an ceoil
feideareachd fonaidh beagan
dheth, dh' fhas Mac ic-Ailein
searbh do gach ni a bh' ann

E fhein 's a chuid ghileanghillean
gun fhois na tamh a latha
na dh' oidhche ach a fritheall
adh 's a deasachadh dha na
biasdan 's gun rathad na
ionleachd aca air fosadh a
chur air am beul 'o itheadh
no idir fosadh a chur air an
cainnt o aoireadh, cha nechan e bha'n
na bha fa'n ach comhair ach
gionallaichean a bha na sin
neadh gu samhach ann an
treuin ghlachabh a bhais
iomadh linn roimhe sin

Coma-co-dhiu chuir Mac-
ic-Ailein cuireadh a dh' ion
nsuidh gach bard 'us rannad-
ear 'us geir-chainntear a bh'air
a chuid fearun, is eadhon feo-
dhuin a as na criochaibh mu'n
cuairt a bh' air an cunntais ro
sgaiteach, 's coma dha sin, cha robh
an gearradaireachd an taca ri
a Chliarsheanachain, ach mar
bhuil' uird air iarrun fuar.

Bha iad a nis teann air bli-
adhna am Baile-nan-Cailleach
Mac-ic Ailein seach seann sg
ith dhuibh, iad air a narachadh
's air a mhaslachadh, a chuid ga
itheadh 's ga ol aca, a chliu
an teugmhail, 's a spreidh a
tannachadh air na raointean.

Thuit e mach lalatha do na
lartheachan lathaichean gun
tubhairt an t-aireach ris nach
biodh speir beo aig do n chrodh
sheasg mar a cuirte air falbh
iad air dhoidhdhoigh eigein. Gu robh
da-fhichead 'us aonan air am
marbhadh mar tha, 's gu feim-
tefeumte raodhne cho math sa bha
sa bhualaidh a mharadhmharbhadh an
diugh a rithist. Nuair a chuala
Mac-ic-Ailein an t-ursgeul so
bhuail e na bassanbasan 's dh' eibh
e na creachan, a'g aslachadh
as uchd Ni-math air gach du-
ine mun Bhaile saod air choir
eigein a dheanaamh gus a fua-
dach air falbh. Bha leith ghlo-
ic do dh' fharas duine sa Bha
ile, aig nach robh moran con
altraidh, ach na theireadh e
bha e cho geur ri sulgh-na-Sea-

div.title: Am Bridein sa'm Fheanag
div.p:
Bha 'm bridein anns an
traigtraigh dluth do n' aite
anns an rorobh nead 'us
bha na h' eoin nan
cruban anns innte. Thanaig
a 'n fheanagfheannag 's shuidh
i air cloich os an
cionn. Ghhab Ghabh
a fear bu mhodha
de na h' eoin ceum a
mach on nead. Ghrad
gheibh a mhathair ris
Ille-bhric-Riabhaich
trodtrothad dhachadhaidh trodtrothad
dhachaidh. Gu h' uige
gu h' uige! ars an
gille breac-riabhach.
Gu n Gu do dhineir! Gu do
dhinnir! Gu de an dhuine
a th' ann, Gu

Bralosgadh is rarely used.
It means a great heap of
every sort of fuel or com-
bustibles collected on an emi-
nence on marriage occasions
or on the coming of age of
Chiefs. Bonfire is the near-
the near near
est word for it I know
I have heard when an extra
big fire was on in winter
and a great many people
reciting tales in a neigh-
bouring house Ubh! ubh be
'm bralosgadh e, air neo ubh!
ubh car son tha leithid sin

Na fir a bha 'n geall air roica

Gach ninnean us mean air –
mointich,

div.p:
Cruaicean a name in olden
times applied to a short thick
stout man of considerable stre-
ngth. Cruaic a short stump
of a tree or a course piece of
timber as generally seen in forests
and timber yards. The name is not
so commonly used now. There was
a man in Rona N.North Uist and he
was known all over the country
as Cruaicean. He emigrated to
America with his family close
upon sixty years ago and his
family is known there as Clann
Chruaicean.

CraidsagCraidseag is the old
gaelic name for a bad joiner
or timber-spoiterspoiler, from Crag
or Cnag a short cutting of timber
A man in North Uist is known
as CraidsagCraidseag and a joiner of the
most primitive style.

Fideadh an old name for
a bad cooper that would use
every sort of timber for all kinds
of vessels and whose workmanship
was not be trusted hoops and
staves always giving away. A man
in Benbecula whom I remember well
was always known as Fideadh
and a bad cooper he was. Some
say that the surname Fiddes is
from Fideadh, the cooper. In olden
times country cooper were numerous
but a good tradesman was known
as Cuipear – cooper.

Dustaidh a modern name for
a bad kelper. The kelp industry
was carried on rigorously on the
West during the later end of last
century and the present. century.
A man that did not burn the
seen sea weed well and in the
usual manner, was known as to
have a great deal of duast
dust, which would require to be
reburnt with some well seasoned
seaweed very carefully. There was
a man in North Uist known as dust-
aidh dust-man after being a season
kelp making in Rona it would not
stick together and the ground officer
who was also kelp officer gave him
a slump sum for his dust and
procured another practical man
to reburn it with his own seed
weedseaweed deducting the allowance made
to dustaidh. I cannot say what
became of dustaidh, but a daugh-
ter of his was in Carinish very
recently have only one issue
as son who was also knowknown
as dustaidh og, young duster.
She was know as nighean ruadh
dhustaidh – red daughter of –
duster. She was a very upright
industrious woman, and never
thought of the name, no more than
her Christian name Mary. May 18 951895

div.title: Tuaireasgeul Mor.
div.p:
How he was put to death or how
Her He went to death, was a wonder-
ful tale. I heard old men well
versed in folk-lore say that it wodwould
take a good resiterreciter seven winter long
nights from beul na hoicheh-oidhche dusk
to Gairm-chailleach cock-crowing
to repeat it in full. In olden times
they used to meet, heads of families
in an appointed place to hear it re-
cited. It was dividedivided into chapters
and each chapter would take a whole
night. Domhnull Ban Dlughallach
Donald Macdougall a famous old
piper of the MacCrimmon school
was considered the best reciter
of his day. His son John who
left Benbecula about thirty
years ago and settled down at Crinan
Canal could recited it word for
word, but not with the same
emphases as his father.
John is still living and one
of his sons is Skipper of one of
the Clutha steamer up & down
on the Clyde. 1895

Feicheantas a common word
in olden times for an arugmentargument
between man and wife about
paltry dispuitsdisputes, especially when
such dispute took place regarding
each other's people.

Cramhan is a continual
low murmuring complainte
by any person kept up for
no other purpose than to keep
on grumbling and dissatisfydissatisfying
others.
